case_name: the assessee v. Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras

facts.text: Civil Appeals No. 218 of 1955 and 219 to 223 of 1955 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals No. 218 of 1955 and 219 to 223 of 1955. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and Order dated September 14, 1951, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras, in I.T.A. No. 3158 of 1949-50.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and Order dated September 14, 1951, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras, in I.T.A. No. 3158 of 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and Order dated September 14, 1951, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras, in I.T.A. No. 3158 of 1949-50. and Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated September, 30, 1953, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras, in I.T.A. Nos. 7840 of 1952-53 and E.P.T.A. Nos. 300, 301 and 302 of 1952-53.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated September 30, 1953, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras, in I.T.A. Nos. 7840 of 1952-53 and E.P.T.A. Nos. 300, 301 and 302 of 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: and Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated September, 30, 1953, of the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras, in I.T.A. Nos. 7840 of 1952-53 and E.P.T.A. Nos. 300, 301 and 302 of 1952-53. Chowdhuri, N. A. Palkhivala and Naunit Lal, for the appellant. N. Sanyal, Additional Solicitor-General of India, Ganapathi lyer and D. Gupta for the respondent. 1960 February 3.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by KAPUR J. on February 3, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960 February 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J. -In these six appeals the companymon question raised is whether the proviso to s. 13 of the Income-tax Act is applicable to the facts and circumstances of these cases. They are therefore disposed of by one judgment.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 218 of 1955 arises out of the assessment for the year 1943-1944.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 218 of 1955 arises out of the assessment for the year 1943-1944. Civil Appeals Nos. 219 to 223 relate to the assessment years 1944-1945, 1946-1947 and for the chargeable accounting periods from January 1943 to February 1944, and from February 1945 to February 1946.

facts.text: Appellant is the assessee, respondent is the Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in each of the appeals is the assessee and the respondent is the Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras. The appellant is a resident and ordinarily resident in India and carried on extensive trade in Colombo in grains, folder, gram and other food-stuffs for cattle and poultry.

facts.text: Appellant is a resident and ordinarily resident in India and carried on extensive trade in Colombo in grains, fodder, gram and other food-stuffs for cattle and poultry.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a resident and ordinarily resident in India and carried on extensive trade in Colombo in grains, folder, gram and other food-stuffs for cattle and poultry. For the assessment year 1943-1944 the appellant showed a turnover of Rs. 17,74,825 and a gross profit of Rs. 63,217 which is about 3.5 per cent.

facts.text: For assessment year 1943-1944, appellant showed turnover of Rs. 17,74,825 and gross profit of Rs. 63,217 (about 3.5%).

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1943-1944 the appellant showed a turnover of Rs. 17,74,825 and a gross profit of Rs. 63,217 which is about 3.5 per cent. For the two previous assessment years the appellants gross profits were 9 per cent and 8 per cent respectively.

facts.text: For two previous assessment years to 1943-44, appellant's gross profits were 9% and 8% respectively.

anchor.surface_text: For the two previous assessment years the appellants gross profits were 9 per cent and 8 per cent respectively. The Income-tax Officer, by his order dated March 20, 1948, rejected the accounts and estimated the gross profit by adding back Rs. 2,38,831 to the returned income.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer by order dated March 20, 1948, rejected accounts, estimated turnover Rs. 20,00,000 and gross income Rs. 3,00,000 (15% profit).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, by his order dated March 20, 1948, rejected the accounts and estimated the gross profit by adding back Rs. 2,38,831 to the returned income. Thus he raised the turnover to Rs. 20,00,000 and the gross income to Rs. 3,00,000 giving a profit of 15 per cent on the estimated turnover.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, the order of the Income-tax Officer was companyfirmed. The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on appeal by its order dated September 14, 1951, after pointing out various defects, rejected the account books but accepted the appellants turnover and companyputed the profits at 15 per cent on grains imported from India and 121 per cent on grains purchased in Ceylon.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by order dated September 14, 1951, rejected account books but accepted turnover and computed profits at 15% on grains imported from India and 12.5% on grains purchased in Ceylon.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal on appeal by its order dated September 14, 1951, after pointing out various defects, rejected the account books but accepted the appellants turnover and companyputed the profits at 15 per cent on grains imported from India and 121 per cent on grains purchased in Ceylon. It held that companyrect profit for the year under assessment companyld number be deduced from the books produced by the appellant.

facts.text: Tribunal held that correct profit for 1943-44 could not be deduced from books produced by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It held that companyrect profit for the year under assessment companyld number be deduced from the books produced by the appellant. The Excess Profits tax for the chargeable accounting period from February 10, 1942 to January 16, 1943, was decided on the basis of the Income- tax assessment for the year 1943-44.

facts.text: Reasons for rejecting accounts: no vouchers for several purchases in Colombo, especially over Rs. 3,00,000; no quantitative tally for grains and materials; payments for licenses and purchases in Tuticorin unexplained; outsiders' cheques entered without proof; investment in India without cash from Colombo.

anchor.surface_text: The reasons it gave were  1  that vouchers for several purchases made in Colombo had number been produced and for purchases of over Rs. 3,00,000 numbervouchers were forthcoming and without the vouchers the entries in the account books companyld -not be verified  2  there was numberquantitative tally for the grains and for other materials purchased by the appellant, which were ground into powder, turned into fodder, packed in different sizes and then sold.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Tribunal on November 21, 1951, for stating a case under s.66(1) on four questions.

anchor.surface_text: On November 21, 1951, the appellant applied to the of Tribunal for stating a case under s. 66 1  on the following four questions Whether under the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was justified in holding that Section 13 of the Indian Income-tax Act applies to the case.

facts.text: Tribunal by order dated February 12, 1950, declined to state a case under s.66(1).

anchor.surface_text: But the Tribunal, by its order dated February 12, 1950, held that numberquestion of law arose and therefore declined to state a case and thus rejected the application.

facts.text: High Court of Madras dismissed application under s.66(2) on February 26, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court of Madras under s. 66 2  of the Act on the same four questions of law. This application was dismissed by the High Court on February 26, 1953.

facts.text: For assessment years 1944-45 and 1946-47, appellant disclosed turnover Rs. 10,35,748 and Rs. 5,98,728, gross profits 10.7% and 8.7%.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1944-1945 and 1946-47 the appellant disclosed a turnover of Rs. 10,35,748 and Rs. 5,98,728 respectively and the gross profits rates were 10.7 per cent and 8.7 per cent respectively.

facts.text: Tribunal applied s.13 and estimated gross profit rates at 12.5% for 1944-45 and 10% for 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: As the books of accounts in regard to these years also were rejected, the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal applied s. 13 and estimated the gross profit rates at 12 1/2 per cent and 10 per cent for the respective years.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Tribunal was justified in applying proviso to s.13 due to defects in accounts.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore when the Tribunal applied the proviso to s. 13 because of the various blemishes which were pointed out by the Income-tax Officer and accepted by the Appellate Tribunal, it cannot be said that there was any error in the order of the Appellate Tribunal justifying the interference of this Court under Art. 136.

facts.text: All six appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result all the six appeals are dismissed with companyts.

Reliance was placed on the judgment of the Punjab High Court in Pandit Brothers v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi  1 .

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguishes Pandit Bros (different facts); stock register important for quantitative tally per Ghanshyam Das; proviso applies on combined defects

arguments.claim: 15% on imported grains and 12.5% on local reasonable given export prohibition, shortage, no price control, manufacturing process

anchor.surface_text: In view of these defects, we are clearly of opinion that the correct profit could not be deduced from the books produced by the assessee, and accordingly hold that proviso to Section 13 of the Act applies in this case. The question, therefore, is regarding the estimate. After giving this finding the Tribunal accepted the turnover as shown in the appellants books. In making the computation of profits the Tribunal took into consideration the following matters that the export of food grains from India was prohibited except under a license, that there was an acute shortage of cattle fodder in Ceylon

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er to lead him to the companyclusion that a proper statement of income, profits and gains companyld number be deduced from the material placed before

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.13 applicable due to account defects; Tribunal justified

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore when the Tribunal applied the proviso to s. 13 because of the various blemishes which were pointed out by the Income-tax Officer and accepted by the Appellate Tribunal, it cannot be said that there was any error in the order of the Appellate Tribunal justifying the interference of this Court under Art. 136.

arguments.claim: No natural justice violation; other cases profits only ancillary support, not basis; distinguishes Dhakeshwari

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, no such case arises in the present appeal. No information, as in Dhakeshwari's Case was supplied to the Tribunal by any one and taken into consideration by it, and therefore it was not necessary to give any such opportunity as the appellant contends for. In the present case the Tribunal has held that from the method of accounting adopted by the appellant correct profits could not be deduced because of the various reasons which have been set out above and the reference to profits made in other cases was only by way of supporting that conclusion.

arguments.claim: Combined defects including lack of stock register justify proviso; distinguishes Pandit Bros; follows Ghanshyam Das, Bombay Cycle, Mac Millan

anchor.surface_text: The facts in that case were very different. ... It cannot therefore be said that that case laid down as a proposition of law that the want of a stock register by which a proper check could be made was not such a serious defect as to make the proviso to s. 13 inapplicable. The importance of such register was pointed out by the Nagpur High Court in Ghanshyam Das Permanand v. Commissioner of Income-tax, C.P. Berar  2 . ... If, after taking into account all the materials including the want of a stock register coupled with other materials they are of the opinion that correct profits and gains cannot be deduced, then they would be justified in applying the proviso to s.

arguments.claim: No error in Tribunal referring to its earlier decision for same assessee

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the Appeal No. 220 of 1955 for the assessment year 1946-1947 the objection raised was that the Tribunal had committed the same error in that it took into consideration the earlier decision of the Tribunal in an identical situation i.e., in the case of the same assessee in regard to previous years. As we have held that there was no error in the order of the Tribunal in regard to the previous years, it cannot be said that this observation of the Tribunal was in any manner erroneous.

holdings.text: The Tribunal was justified in applying the proviso to s. 13 of the Income-tax Act because of various defects in the assessee's accounts, and there was no error warranting interference under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore when the Tribunal applied the proviso to s. 13 because of the various blemishes which were pointed out by the Income-tax Officer and accepted by the Appellate Tribunal, it cannot be said that there was any error in the order of the Appellate Tribunal justifying the interference of this Court under Art. 136.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multiple defects in accounts (lack of vouchers for purchases over Rs. 3 lakhs, no quantitative tally, unexplained payments for licenses and purchases, outsiders' cheques without proof, investments without corresponding cash receipts) prevented proper deduction of profits; Tribunal correctly rejected books and estimated profits.

holdings.text: There was no violation of principles of natural justice as the Tribunal did not rely on undisclosed material from other cases as the basis for estimation; such references were merely ancillary support.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, no such case arises in the present appeal. No information, as in Dhakeshwari's Case was supplied to the Tribunal by any one and taken into consideration by it, and therefore it was not necessary to give any such opportunity as the appellant contends for. In the present case the Tribunal has held that from the method of accounting adopted by the appellant correct profits could not be deduced because of the various reasons which have been set out above and the reference to profits made in other cases was only by way of supporting that conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Dhakeshwari Cotton Mills as no secret external information was supplied and used as basis; primary basis was assessee's own defective accounts; other cases' profits only supportive.

holdings.text: The combined defects, including absence of stock register and manufacturing accounts, justify rejection of books and application of proviso to s. 13.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be said that that case laid down as a proposition of law that the want of a stock register by which a proper check could be made was not such a serious defect as to make the proviso to s. 13 inapplicable. The importance of such register was pointed out by the Nagpur High Court in Ghanshyam Das Permanand v. Commissioner of Income-tax, C.P. Berar. In cases such as the instant case, the keeping of a stock register is of great importance because that is a means of verifying the assessee's accounts by having a quantitative tally. If, after taking into account all the materials including the want of a stock register coupled with other materials they are of the opinion that correct profits and gains cannot be deduced, then they would be justified in applying the proviso to s.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Pandit Brothers on different facts where accounts were otherwise correct; follows Ghanshyam Das, Bombay Cycle Stores, and Mac Millan on need for quantitative verification and authority to reject despite regular method if profits not properly deductible.

holdings.text: Income-tax authorities are not bound by the figure of profits shown in the assessee's accounts even if the method of accounting is accepted.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be added, as was held by this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Mac Millan Co., that the Income-tax Officer, even if he accepts the assessees method of accounting, is not bound by the figure of profits shown in the accounts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies existing Supreme Court precedent in Mac Millan Co. and Bombay Cycle Stores that acceptance of method does not compel acceptance of profit figures if unreliable.

holdings.text: No error in the Tribunal considering its earlier decision for the same assessee in identical situation for assessment year 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: As we have held that there was no error in the order of the Tribunal in regard to the previous years, it cannot be said that this observation of the Tribunal was in any manner erroneous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior holdings upheld; consistency in same assessee's cases not erroneous.

The initial application initiates the procedural chain leading to Art. 136 consideration.
Appellant's application to Tribunal provides context triggering the issue of error in Tribunal's order on that application.
The Tribunal's order triggers the court's assessment and decision under Art. 136 that no error warrants interference.
The Tribunal's order declining to state a case is the precise order referenced in the issue questioning error therein.
High Court's dismissal completes prior remedies, triggering Art. 136 non-interference decision.
High Court's dismissal escalates the matter, triggering the Art. 136 issue on Tribunal error.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore when the Tribunal applied the proviso to s. 13 because of the various blemishes which were pointed out by the Income-tax Officer and accepted by the Appellate Tribunal, it cannot be said that there was any error in the order of the Appellate Tribunal justifying the interference of this Court under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, no such case arises in the present appeal. No information, as in Dhakeshwari's Case was supplied to the Tribunal by any one and taken into consideration by it, and therefore it was not necessary to give any such opportunity as the appellant contends for. In the present case the Tribunal has held that from the method of accounting adopted by the appellant correct profits could not be deduced because of the various reasons which have been set out above and the reference to profits made in other cases was only by way of supporting that conclusion.
In the result all the six appeals are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be said that that case laid down as a proposition of law that the want of a stock register by which a proper check could be made was not such a serious defect as to make the proviso to s. 13 inapplicable. The importance of such register was pointed out by the Nagpur High Court in Ghanshyam Das Permanand v. Commissioner of Income-tax, C.P. Berar. In cases such as the instant case, the keeping of a stock register is of great importance because that is a means of verifying the assessee's accounts by having a quantitative tally. If, after taking into account all the materials including the want of a stock register coupled with other materials they are of the opinion that correct profits and gains cannot be deduced, then they would be justified in applying the proviso to s.
In the result all the six appeals are dismissed with companyts.

Ghanshyam Das emphasizes stock register importance for verifying accounts, supporting defects condition in c2
